content:
That's great to hear that you've already made your own simple syrup! Substituting it in the Lavender Honey Spritz recipe can definitely work, but it depends on the flavor profile of your simple syrup.

Since you didn't specify the flavor of your simple syrup, I'll provide some general guidelines:

* If your simple syrup is flavored with a complementary ingredient like lemon, orange, or grapefruit, it might work well in the Lavender Honey Spritz. The citrus notes will complement the honey and gin nicely.
* If your simple syrup is flavored with a spicy or warm ingredient like cinnamon, ginger, or chili, it might clash with the delicate flavor of the lavender. You might want to start with a small amount and adjust to taste.
* If your simple syrup is flavored with a sweet ingredient like vanilla, caramel, or fruit (e.g., strawberry or raspberry), it might make the drink overly sweet. You might want to reduce the amount of simple syrup or balance it with a bit more lemon juice.

To make the substitution, start by using the same amount of your simple syrup as the recipe calls for (1/2 oz). Taste the drink and adjust to your liking. You can always add more simple syrup, but it's harder to remove excess sweetness.

If you're unsure, you could also try creating a mini-batch of the cocktail with your simple syrup before serving it to your guests. This will give you a chance to taste and adjust the flavors before the party.

Remember, the beauty of mixology lies in experimentation and creativity. Don't be afraid to try new things and adjust recipes to your taste. Your signature cocktail might just become a hit at your dinner party!

What's the flavor profile of your simple syrup, if you don't mind me asking? I might be able to provide more specific guidance.
